subject: ACEP Website Vulnerablity
description:
Hi Vanessa,

I realize that I have not officially started yet but I was familiarizing myself with the ACEP team on the ACEP website when I discovered a minor security issue which allows anyone on the Internet to modify the ACEP directory details.  I wanted to bring this to your attention.  Please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions or need assistance.

**Summary**

The lax sharing setting on the [ACEP team database](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1iQU9tqWi0De4E0Da7pn4G7cADmtr0srJx9bLG4PwjWw/edit#gid=0) google spreadsheet permits anyone with the like to modify the content.  This makes it very easy for anyone to deface the ACEP website team directory with malicious or embarrassing content.  This includes modifying directory metadata and replacing people's headshot image URL links with other images.

**Risks and Impacts**

*   Likelihood:  Low to Moderate
*   Impact: Moderate

The chances that someone or some botnet will find and exploit this risk is very possible, but not likely as it has not yet been exploited.  If this vulnerability is exploited the impacts to ACEP may include:

*   Possible loss of directory information making it difficult to recover.
*   Embarrassment and loss of confidence in ACEP resulting from a defaced website.
*   Social Engineering or redirected contact info for identity theft or other malicious purposes.

**Recommended Resolution**

1.  Designate individual persons (@[alaska.edu](http://alaska.edu/) accounts) _**Editor**_ access to the [ACEP team database](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1iQU9tqWi0De4E0Da7pn4G7cADmtr0srJx9bLG4PwjWw/edit#gid=0) [Spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1iQU9tqWi0De4E0Da7pn4G7cADmtr0srJx9bLG4PwjWw/edit#gid=0) Share option.
2.  Change the Sharing permissions for General Access to:  _**Anyone with the link:  Viewer**_

This will give explicit permission to those who need edit permission, yet still allow anyone (and any website) on the Internet the ability to view the spreadsheet details.

**Incident / Vulnerability Reporting**

I assume this ACEP Website is an OU Campus website administered by OIT.

*   If so then OIT may have also set up directory pages for other departments in a similar manner.
*   I would advise forwarding this email to the UA OIT security group: [security@alaska.edu](mailto:security@alaska.edu)
*   Or submit a ticket via: [https://www.alaska.edu/securitymatters/](https://www.alaska.edu/securitymatters/)

**Technical Details**

*   From the Team directory page: [https://www.uaf.edu/acep/about/our-team/index.php](https://www.uaf.edu/acep/about/our-team/index.php)
*   One can see that the site loads the script: [https://www.uaf.edu/acep/about/our-team/directory.js](https://www.uaf.edu/acep/about/our-team/directory.js)
*   Which contains the ACEP team database Google Spreadsheet link: [https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1iQU9tqWi0De4E0Da7pn4G7cADmtr0srJx9bLG4PwjWw/edit#gid=0](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1iQU9tqWi0De4E0Da7pn4G7cADmtr0srJx9bLG4PwjWw/edit#gid=0)

![](https://media-protected.taiga.io/attachments/6/e/b/c/ef9616926a162fbc6f9f6b20056b4afd55735cc89087f7510d0b32c103fa/screenshot-from-2023-08-28-12-40-53.png?token=ZQTNUA%3AGAHMW5QJS9tSSKsA0Cv9msBYSKKPYCb85ak8Pjz7bHFqYmPu-xKiPTkh-7d6tpS9d9Zz33_MVyYfZPEW20jFQg#_taiga-refresh=issue:1957776)

*   The **Share** setting for this spreadsheet permits _**Anyone with the link**_ full Edit permissions to the spreadsheet.

![](https://media-protected.taiga.io/attachments/d/f/3/3/c9df488e02d0dee55f4b5f347be15d24a3f4b393ef4a9547d2fd3a23e80d/screenshot-from-2023-08-28-12-42-28.png?token=ZQTNaA%3Ay3tEHaLSGZwEIFWxrpuYcIrXSQUGYg0DkMi1EnVIJhOZDNVlwPiMD6uZoQ7AVKkZhHTZIIcYrhiv_A_MPJTouw#_taiga-refresh=issue:1957777)

subject: Firefox WebP Patch
description:
Issue
-----

[https://thehackernews.com/2023/09/mozilla-rushes-to-patch-webp-critical.html](https://thehackernews.com/2023/09/mozilla-rushes-to-patch-webp-critical.html)

[https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-4863](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-4863)

Resolution
----------

**Upgrade**: It has been addressed in Firefox 117.0.1, Firefox ESR 115.2.1, Firefox ESR 102.15.1, Thunderbird 102.15.1, and Thunderbird 115.2.2.

**Upgrade** to Google Chrome more recent than 116.0.5845.187

Action Items
------------

*   [ ] Communicated Updates for Firefox, Thunderbird and Chrome

subject: HR Enrollment Updates
description:
Hello John,

Congratulations! Your new position has been entered into the Banner system. You do not need to do anything at this time. If you would like to update your direct deposit or W-4, please see the instructions below.

**Direct Deposit and W-4**

1) If you would like direct deposit, please follow this link to fill out a request online: [https://www.alaska.edu/hr/forms/hr\_payrollforms/](https://www.alaska.edu/hr/forms/hr_payrollforms/) and click on the link under (payroll) Direct Deposit Request Form.

2) Please log in using your UA username and password and complete your W-4 at [https://nextgensso.com/sp/startSSO.ping?PartnerIdpId=urn:mace:incommon:alaska.edu&TargetResource=https%3a%2f%2fdynamicforms.ngwebsolutions.com%2fSubmit%2fStart%2fa2a3ecdf-ba79-4d4d-9c7e-7e40400b51c2](https://nextgensso.com/sp/startSSO.ping?PartnerIdpId=urn:mace:incommon:alaska.edu&TargetResource=https%3a%2f%2fdynamicforms.ngwebsolutions.com%2fSubmit%2fStart%2fa2a3ecdf-ba79-4d4d-9c7e-7e40400b51c2)

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Thank you,

\--

subject: 2023-09-14 ARCTIC Site Visit
description:
Hi all,

[2023 ARCTIC site visit - Daily Agenda](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Iidyy5RYRzK51SJO79NJb24139Vqafu8qd5olXnrZyA/edit?usp=sharing)

[2023 ARCTIC site visit - Google Calendar](https://calendar.google.com/calendar/u/0?cid=Y19kNjhhYTNkZjhhYjBmOTMwZjYwZDc5OTRjNmVmYmE5ZGFlNGJlOTFiMTMwMzg5MDRlOGZkZjZkYjFmNmVjMjAzQGdyb3VwLmNhbGVuZGFyLmdvb2dsZS5jb20)

As promised, here is the agenda for the ARCTIC site visit happening next week. ONR's Michele Anderson and Mike Resner arrive in Anchorage tomorrow and will depart Saturday after a whirlwind tour of Anchorage, Fairbanks, and Kotzebue. During this time ARCTIC researchers & leadership will be presenting on ARCTIC research and community engagement:

*   Monday morning in Anchorage,
*   Thursday all day in Fairbanks, and
*   Friday all day in Kotzebue

This year's site visit also features some different approaches to updating our program officers including facilitated conversations with other decision-makers and federal funders in Alaska, and an interactive presentation style in the form of a guided poster session.

**ARCTIC mixer: Community & Energy Futures**

Monday 9/11 5pm  
 

King Street Brewing, Anchorage

& 

Friday 9/15 5pm  
 

Alaska Technical Center, Kotzebue

**ARCTIC poster session**

Thursday 9/14 2 - 4pm

BP Design Center, Fairbanks

With all of these activities we hope to best represent the important and prescient research of ACEP and ARCTIC partners and to convey to ONR all the ways in which our work supports Alaskan communities and energy transitions.

Best,

Vanessa & Dayne

  
 

**Vanessa Raymond**

[vlraymond@alaska.edu](mailto:vlraymond@alaska.edu)

**Data Governance Lead** & **ARCTIC Program Manager**

_Alaska Center for Energy and Power, University of Alaska Fairbanks, Troth Yeddha' Campus_ 

_Grateful to live & work on the land of the Lower Tanana Dene_

**Nerd out with me @** Arctic Data Committee (candidate co-chair) | IARPC Data Management (non-federal co-lead) | US AON Expert Committee on Methods (member)

subject: 2023-09-15 Web Development w John - Meet & Greet
Review ACEP GAP Accessment
description:
**John Haverlack**  [10:31 AM](https://ualaska.slack.com/archives/D03MFJEGCE9/p1694457092143259)  
 

Do you know if ACEP's GAP assessment can be shared with me?

[10:31](https://ualaska.slack.com/archives/D03MFJEGCE9/p1694457108582359)

Today is my first day.

![](https://ca.slack-edge.com/T0GEDA3L7-U03MANCG1Q8-9e6670161428-48)

**Raina Collins**  [10:32 AM](https://ualaska.slack.com/archives/D03MFJEGCE9/p1694457121713159)  
 

totally but I haven't done it yet LOL  
I'm very behind on all my reportin

![](https://ca.slack-edge.com/T0GEDA3L7-U0Z8G6YMQ-24f6a3dd1637-48)

**John Haverlack**  [10:32 AM](https://ualaska.slack.com/archives/D03MFJEGCE9/p1694457140474329)  
 

Gotcha.  Thanks for the quick response.

[10:33](https://ualaska.slack.com/archives/D03MFJEGCE9/p1694457193725999)

Do you have a template of the GAP question you ask that you'd be able to share with me?

[10:33](https://ualaska.slack.com/archives/D03MFJEGCE9/p1694457211544949)

If not that's ok.

![](https://ca.slack-edge.com/T0GEDA3L7-U03MANCG1Q8-9e6670161428-48)

**Raina Collins**  [10:36 AM](https://ualaska.slack.com/archives/D03MFJEGCE9/p1694457380206959)  
 

I can share the notes from when they were there - basically I'm asking the questions from CMMC 2.0 Level 1 - if they can become compliant with those then they'll meet Sean's goal for departmental cyber hygiene - the problem with ACEP and Sikuliaq is that there are business processes separate from research processes - so when we interviewed ACEP, Dayne was very clear on the separation - which I'm in full agreement of. The devices/users that deal with CUI are different than the devices/users that attend to the business processes

![](https://ca.slack-edge.com/T0GEDA3L7-U0Z8G6YMQ-24f6a3dd1637-48)

**John Haverlack**  [10:37 AM](https://ualaska.slack.com/archives/D03MFJEGCE9/p1694457476443689)  
 

Understood.  I'll stand by for now.   Separation is good but often difficult to structure.

subject: DDoS 2.0: IoT Sparks New DDoS Alert
description:
Issue
-----

[https://thehackernews.com/2023/09/ddos-20-iot-sparks-new-ddos-alert.html](https://thehackernews.com/2023/09/ddos-20-iot-sparks-new-ddos-alert.html)

Resolution
----------

*   [ ] Communicate to Data Team

**Defensive Measures: Strategies and Best Practices**[**#**](https://thehackernews.com/2023/09/ddos-20-iot-sparks-new-ddos-alert.html#defensive-measures-strategies-and-best-practices)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The rise of more sophisticated and powerful attacks makes immediate attention to security essential. Here's how various stakeholders can contribute to a more secure digital ecosystem:

#### **1\. Protect your IoT from being infected.**[**#**](https://thehackernews.com/2023/09/ddos-20-iot-sparks-new-ddos-alert.html#1-protect-your-iot-from-being-infected)

*   **Educate on safe IoT practices:** Encourage home and corporate users to change default passwords, update firmware, and adhere to best practices to prevent devices from being compromised. Many companies, like [SANS Institute](https://www.sans.org/cyber-security-courses/iot-penetration-testing/), offer training on IoT security and penetration testing.
*   **Collaborate and threat share:** Initiatives like the [Cyber Threat Alliance](https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org/) and the [Joint Cyber Defense Collaborative](https://www.cisa.gov/topics/partnerships-and-collaboration/joint-cyber-defense-collaborative) unite governments, tech companies, and cybersecurity firms to rapidly detect and neutralize emerging threats, strengthening collective global defenses.
*   **Regularly update devices:** Ensure IoT devices are updated with the latest firmware and patches to prevent known vulnerabilities from being exploited.

#### **2\. Protect against IoT-driven botnet DDoS attacks.**[**#**](https://thehackernews.com/2023/09/ddos-20-iot-sparks-new-ddos-alert.html#2-protect-against-iotdriven-botnet-ddos-attacks)

*   **Implement multi-layer security protocols**: Deploy a [comprehensive security strategy](https://gcore.com/learning/cybersecurity-solutions-overview/), from firewalls and intrusion detection systems to web application security solutions.
*   **Invest in** [**Specialized DDoS Protection Solutions**](https://gcore.com/ddos-protection?utm_source=thehackernews&utm_medium=article&utm_campaign=iot): Companies like Gcore have developed solutions explicitly designed to combat even massive, IoT-driven DDoS attacks. These DDoS protection solutions have been pivotal in reducing risks by leveraging real-time analytics.

Hi Jennifer,

NOT URGENT, PLEASE RESPOND AS YOU HAVE TIME.

I'm interested in maybe creating a few ACEP UAF Google Groups / Departmental Accounts and wanted to consult with your first before doing so.  There is no rush on this so we can talk when you have time.

If ACEP already has SOP's related to managing ACEP Google Group and Departmental accounts I would like to follow those practices.  If not I'm happy to advise on a few simple practices that can simplify business continuity considerations for ACEP in this regard.   Again there is no urgency on this matter.

The emails I'm interested in creating are:

Hi Alex: Thanks for reaching out! I'd be happy to jump on a call. I've added a few people to this thread: * Mr. John Haverlack has been with UAF for awhile, but recently joined the ACEP team to work on cybersecurity * Mr. Tom Hough is the UAF DoD Liaison and may have some ideas of other cybersecurity experts at UAF that could be a helpful as a resource * Mr. Jeremy Kasper, ACEP Director, is BCC'd for situational awareness I've got a great relationship with both ToniAnn and Claire, and I know UAF is very interested in more partnerships with the Air Force. With the increasing concern and interest in this area, I believe it's a great opportunity for UAF to support such an effort. Thanks for thinking of us! Thanks, **Brittany Smart** Energy Transitions Initiative Coordinator [ACEP](https://www.uaf.edu/acep/) | [UAF](https://www.uaf.edu/uaf/) Cell: (808) 989-6110     On Sat, Sep 16, 2023 at 4:02 PM Brickner, Alex M <[Alex\_Brickner@uml.edu](mailto:Alex_Brickner@uml.edu)\> wrote:   > Brittney, > > Thank you so much for offering to support our work on the ADC Cyber Workforce and Research working group! > > We had our first meeting last week and identified a strong need to connect defense communities with state research universities.  Your name came up given your work with the University of Alaska Fairbanks(UAF) and community partnership discussions at the Alaska Defense Forum. > > **Are you open to a brief call with Dan and myself to review working group activities and brainstorm several potential directions?** > > For additional context, UMLARC just executed a corporative research and development agreement (CRADA) with the 66th ABG related to defense community research that may be useful to UAF.  The CRADA will be used to develop defense community information sharing agreements.  ToniAnn Fisher and Claire Reynolds are tracking and helping us overcome policy barriers. > > >   > > **Alex Brickner** > > Director - SBIR Programs, UMass Lowell Applied Research Corporation > > 55 Old Bedford Rd, Suite 100 > > Lincoln, MA 01773 > > Cell: 847-275-5327 > > [https://umlarc.org/](https://umlarc.org/) >   > > [https://northstarcampus.org/](https://northstarcampus.org/)

subject: CMMC L1 Review / GAP Accessment / POAM
description:
CMMC L1
-------

[https://dodcio.defense.gov/Portals/0/Documents/CMMC/AG\_Level1\_V2.0\_FinalDraft\_20211210\_508.pdf](https://dodcio.defense.gov/Portals/0/Documents/CMMC/AG_Level1_V2.0_FinalDraft_20211210_508.pdf)

### Terminology

*   Federal Contract Information (FCI)
*   Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR)
*   Supplier Performance Risk System ([SPRS](https://www.sprs.csd.disa.mil/)) - Registration is at Institution Level
*   Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI)
*   External Service Provider (ESP)
*   AC Access Control
*   CD-ROM Compact Disk Read-Only Memory
*   CMMC Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification
*   CUI Controlled Unclassified Information
*   CVE Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures
*   CWE Common Weakness Enumeration
*   DFARS Defense Federal Acquisition Regulation Supplement
*   DMZ Demilitarized Zone
*   DoD Department of Defense
*   ESP External Service Provider
*   FAR Federal Acquisition Regulation
*   FCI Federal Contract Information
*   ID Identification
*   IT Information Technology
*   LAN Local Area Network
*   MEP Manufacturing Extension Partnership
*   NIST National Institute of Standards and Technology
*   PIV Personal Identity Verification
*   SC System and Communications Protection
*   SI System and Information Integrity
*   SP Special Publication
*   SPRS Supplier Performance Risk System
*   USB Universal Serial Bus
*   UUENCODE Unix-to-Unix Encode
*   VLAN Virtual Local Area Network

### Organization

#### Self-Assessment and Compliance

> A contractor can be in compliance with CMMC Level 1 practices for an entire enterprise network or for particular enclave(s), depending upon where the FCI is or will be processed, stored, or transmitted. 
> 
> For a CMMC Level 1 self-assessment, the assets that process, store, or transmit FCI are considered inscope and should be assessed against the CMMC Level 1 practices

#### CMMC-Specific Terms

*   Asset (Organizational Asset)
*   Component:
*   Information System (IS):
*   Monitor
*   Organizationally Defined

#### Self-Assessment Criteria and Methodology

[NIST Special Publication (SP) 800-171A](https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/SpecialPublications/NIST.SP.800-171a.pdf) Section 2.1 focuses on Controlled Unclassified Information        
(CUI)

*   Specifications
*   Mechanisms
*   Activities
*   Individuals or groups of individuals

Methodology

*   The examine method
*   The interview method
*   The test method

Findings

*   MET
*   NOT MET
*   NOT APPLICABLE (N/A)

#### Practice Descriptions

*   Practice Number, Name, and Statement
*   Assessment Objectives \[NIST SP 800-171A\]
*   Potential Assessment Methods and Objects \[NIST SP 800-171A\]
*   Discussion \[NIST SP 800-171 R2\]
*   Further Discussion
*   Key References (The CMMC Model Overview, Appendix B: Source Mapping)

Controls
--------

### Access Control (AC)

#### AC.L1-3.1.1 – AUTHORIZED ACCESS CONTROL

Determine if:     
\[a\] authorized users are identified;     
\[b\] processes acting on behalf of authorized users are identified;     
\[c\] devices (and other systems) authorized to connect to the system are identified;     
\[d\] system access is limited to authorized users;     
\[e\] system access is limited to processes acting on behalf of authorized users; and     
\[f\] system access is limited to authorized devices (including other systems).

#### AC.L1-3.1.2 – TRANSACTION & FUNCTION CONTROL

Determine if:     
\[a\] the types of transactions and functions that authorized users are permitted to execute     
are defined; and     
\[b\] system access is limited to the defined types of transactions and functions for     
authorized users.

#### AC.L1-3.1.20 – EXTERNAL CONNECTIONS

Determine if:     
\[a\] connections to external systems are identified;     
\[b\] the use of external systems is identified;     
\[c\] connections to external systems are verified;     
\[d\] the use of external systems is verified;     
\[e\] connections to external systems are controlled/limited; and     
\[f\] the use of external systems is controlled/limited.

#### AC.L1-3.1.22 – CONTROL PUBLIC INFORMATION

Determine if:     
\[a\] individuals authorized to post or process information on publicly accessible systems     
are identified;     
\[b\] procedures to ensure FCI is not posted or processed on publicly accessible systems are     
identified;     
\[c\] a review process is in place prior to posting of any content to publicly accessible     
systems;     
\[d\] content on publicly accessible systems is reviewed to ensure that it does not include     
FCI; and     
\[e\] mechanisms are in place to remove and address improper posting of FCI. 

### Identification and Authentication (IA)

#### IA.L1-3.5.1 – IDENTIFICATION

Determine if:     
\[a\] system users are identified;     
\[b\] processes acting on behalf of users are identified; and     
\[c\] devices accessing the system are identified.

#### IA.L1-3.5.2 – AUTHENTICATION

Determine if:     
\[a\] the identity of each user is authenticated or verified as a prerequisite to system access;     
\[b\] the identity of each process acting on behalf of a user is authenticated or verified as a     
prerequisite to system access; and     
\[c\] the identity of each device accessing or connecting to the system is authenticated or     
verified as a prerequisite to system access.

### Media Protection (MP)

#### P.L1-3.8.3 – MEDIA DISPOSAL

Determine if:     
\[a\] system media containing FCI is sanitized or destroyed before disposal; and     
\[b\] system media containing FCI is sanitized before it is released for reuse

### Physical Protection (PE)

#### PE.L1-3.10.1 – LIMIT PHYSICAL ACCESS

Determine if:     
\[a\] authorized individuals allowed physical access are identified;     
\[b\] physical access to organizational systems is limited to authorized individuals;     
\[c\] physical access to equipment is limited to authorized individuals; and     
\[d\] physical access to operating environments is limited to authorized individuals. 

#### PE.L1-3.10.3 – ESCORT VISITORS

Determine if:     
\[a\] visitors are escorted; and     
\[b\] visitor activity is monitored.

#### PE.L1-3.10.4 – PHYSICAL ACCESS LOGS

Determine if:    
\[a\] audit logs of physical access are maintained.

#### PE.L1-3.10.5 – MANAGE PHYSICAL ACCESS

Determine if:    
\[a\] physical access devices are identified;    
\[b\] physical access devices are controlled; and    
\[c\] physical access devices are managed.

### System and Communications Protection (SC)

#### SC.L1-3.13.1 – BOUNDARY PROTECTION

Determine if:    
\[a\] the external system boundary is defined;    
\[b\] key internal system boundaries are defined;    
\[c\] communications are monitored at the external system boundary;    
\[d\] communications are monitored at key internal boundaries;    
\[e\] communications are controlled at the external system boundary;    
\[f\] communications are controlled at key internal boundaries;    
\[g\] communications are protected at the external system boundary; and    
\[h\] communications are protected at key internal boundaries.

#### SC.L1-3.13.5 – PUBLIC-ACCESS SYSTEM SEPARATION

Determine if:    
\[a\] publicly accessible system components are identified; and    
\[b\] subnetworks for publicly accessible system components are physically or logically    
separated from internal networks. 

### System and Information Integrity (SI)

#### SI.L1-3.14.1 – FLAW REMEDIATION

Determine if:    
\[a\] the time within which to identify system flaws is specified;    
\[b\] system flaws are identified within the specified time frame;    
\[c\] the time within which to report system flaws is specified;    
\[d\] system flaws are reported within the specified time frame;    
\[e\] the time within which to correct system flaws is specified; and    
\[f\] system flaws are corrected within the specified time frame.

#### SI.L1-3.14.2 – MALICIOUS CODE PROECTION

Determine if:    
\[a\] designated locations for malicious code protection are identified; and    
\[b\] protection from malicious code at designated locations is provided.

#### SI.L1-3.14.4 – UPDATE MALICIOUS CODE PROTECTION

Determine if:    
\[a\] malicious code protection mechanisms are updated when new releases are available.

#### SI.L1-3.14.5 – SYSTEM & FILE SCANNING

Determine if:    
\[a\] the frequency for malicious code scans is defined;    
\[b\] malicious code scans are performed with the defined frequency; and    
\[c\] real-time malicious code scans of files from external sources as files are downloaded,    
opened, or executed are performed.

subject: KEA ACT1 Competition
description:
> Met with KEA Team to fill in missing content and answer questions.  Submission by KEA is dues Nov 29.  Materials are 90% completed.  We will meet again early 

Advanced Cybersecurity Technology (ACT) 1 Competition
-----------------------------------------------------

Advanced Cybersecurity Technology (ACT) 1  Rural and Municipal Utility Cybersecurity (RMUC) Program

[ACEP KEA - Google Shared Drive](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0AP_aiG8YtMbsUk9PVA)

[KEA Team - https://www.herox.com/ACT1Prize/team/23232/forum](https://www.herox.com/ACT1Prize/team/23232/forum)

For Kotzebue Electric Association
---------------------------------

*   2023-09-22 Prepared by John Haverlack, Information Security Manager, Alaska Center for Energy and Power

Summary
-------

*   [https://www.herox.com/ACT1Prize](https://www.herox.com/ACT1Prize)

> The Rural and Municipal Utility Cybersecurity (RMUC) Program invites electric cooperative, municipal, and small investor-owned utilities with limited cybersecurity resources and utilities that serve military installations to apply for competitive funding and technical assistance through the Advanced Cybersecurity Technology (ACT) 1 Prize.

#### Links

*   [https://www.herox.com/ACT1Prize](https://www.herox.com/ACT1Prize)
*   [https://americanmadechallenges.org/challenges/act/docs/ACT-1-Official-Prize-Rules.pdf](https://americanmadechallenges.org/challenges/act/docs/ACT-1-Official-Prize-Rules.pdf)

URGENT Action Items
-------------------

All ACT 1 Prize competitors will be required to complete two webinars scheduled for September 27 and October 11, 2023.

*   Register for [Workshop 1: Prize Overview and How to Compete](https://nrel.zoomgov.com/webinar/register/WN_bJwxRqSsTu6ljDvpe55ceA) – Sept. 27, 2023, 1 p.m. ET (09:00 AK)
*   Register for [Workshop 2: How Future Prize Phases Will Work](https://nrel.zoomgov.com/webinar/register/WN_a0DH-0qIT-irw55uGqMzQQ) – Oct. 11, 2023, 1 p.m. ET  (09:00 AK)

**AS SOON AS POSSIBLE**: Before Sept 27th we will need to:

*   Set up a meeting, Ideally on Monday Sept 25 with John Haverlack (jehaverlack@alaska.edu)  to overview the competition requirements and KEA responsiblies.
*   Identify WHO will be registering and submiting documents on behalf of KEA.  I recommend identifying a point persons at KEA to do so and can explain why in persons.  **ACEP can assist with much of the submission preparation, but the competition entry should be completed by KEA persons.**
*   Register for [Workshop 1: Prize Overview and How to Compete](https://nrel.zoomgov.com/webinar/register/WN_bJwxRqSsTu6ljDvpe55ceA) – Sept. 27, 2023, 1 p.m. ET (09:00 AK)
*   Identify ACEP resource allocation and roles to assist KEA.
*   Recommend KEA Legal Council review and accept Terms of Service, Liability Waivers, and Records Retention and Freedom of Information Act considerations for this competition.

Timeline
--------

*   2023-09-25 - Meeting with ACEP to review an prepare for HeroX / Workshop 1 Registration
*   2023-09-27 - [Workshop 1: Prize Overview and How to Compete](https://nrel.zoomgov.com/webinar/register/WN_bJwxRqSsTu6ljDvpe55ceA) – Sept. 27, 2023, 1 p.m. ET (09:00 AK)
*   2023-11-29 - ACT 1 Phase 1 submission packages are due November 29, 2023, at 5:00 p.m. ET.

Roles (Proposed / TBD)
----------------------

*   KEA Point of Contact and Competition Submitter
*   ACEP Project Manager - John Haverlack [(jehaverlack@alaska.edu]((jehaverlack@alaska.edu))
*   ACEP Techinical Liaison - Solomon Himelbloom [(sbhimelbloom@alaska.edu]((sbhimelbloom@alaska.edu))
*   ACEP Techinical Liaison - Dayne Broderson [(dbbroderson@alaska.edu]((dbbroderson@alaska.edu))

* * *

TL-DR;
------

ACT 1 Phase 1 Commitment Submission
-----------------------------------

> Phase 1. Commitment: utilities describe their resources, need for improving their cybersecurity                       
> posture, and commitment to participating in the ACT 1 Prize Program.

*   Submission Due 2023-11-29
*   Describe need, goals, service territory, and demonstrate commitment
*   Prize Awarded to ~55 winners ~March 2024
*   Award: $50k / 60 hours Technical Assistance

> Funding is provided to winners for work that has already been performed. Once a prize is awarded, winners determine how best to use the funds, with no further commitments.

#### 1.1 Goal

> The goal of the Commitment Phase is to begin identifying the cybersecurity improvements your utility                 
> would like to accomplish and gaining your leadership’s commitment to making improvements. In the                 
> Commitment Phase, you will describe why your utility should qualify as a limited cybersecurity resources                 
> utility if you are competing in the LIMITED CYBERSECURITY RESOURCES track. Utilities in both tracks                 
> must describe the utility’s current cybersecurity maturity level and demonstrate in your submission                 
> package that your utility and its staff have the capacity to work with TA providers. Utilities will need to                 
> provide a letter of support from their authorizing official (CEO, general manager, or governing board)                 
> supporting staff resources and time to this effort and affirming the utility’s commitment to fully                 
> participate. The RMUC Program recognizes the economic challenges many rural communities face, and                 
> competitors will also be asked to describe their utility service territory, the communities they serve, and                 
> the work they do to support disadvantaged communities in their service territory.                 
> Submission packages for the Commitment Prize will be evaluated based on the following criteria (See                 
> Section 1.4 for more information):
> 
> *   Criterion 1: **Utility Need and Cybersecurity Maturity Level**
> *   Criterion 2: **Initial Goals, Expected Outcomes, and Impacts on Utility**
> *   Criterion 3: **Commitment to Implement Cybersecurity Improvements and Capacity to Utilize TA**
> *   Criterion 4: **Description of Service Territory and Community Benefits**.
> 
> Priority will be given to utilities that have limited cybersecurity resources and cybersecurity capabilities,                 
> have a commitment and capacity to work with TA providers, have strong leadership support, and/or serve                 
> a high proportion of low-income and disadvantaged communities.

#### 1.3 What to Submit for the Commitment Prize

> To apply for a Commitment Prize, the utility must:
> 
> • **Have a staff member attend two required ACT 1 Prize Program workshops**
> 
> • Upload a submission package that includes all the items listed below:
> 
> 1\. **Cover page and narrative**
> 
> 2\. **Letter of support from your organization’s authorizing official (e.g., CEO, general manager, board of directors, etc.)**
> 
> 3\. **Utility Profile Form (use form provided) Page 13 of 45**
> 
> 4\. **RMUC Utility Service Territory Report (use Report provided)**
> 
> 5\. **TA Request Form (use form provided)**
> 
> 6\. **Mandatory ACT 1 Prize virtual workshops attendance confirmation.**

#### ACT 1 prize winners will: 

*   Develop network architectures of their digital systems to identify and prioritize where interventions might be most effective
*   Assess current cybersecurity technical stacks for gaps, duplication of functions, and opportunities to fully utilize existing capabilities
*   Create cybersecurity plans and roadmaps to improve their cybersecurity posture
*   Identify solutions that can be operated and maintained by existing staff and budgets
*   Develop budgets, cost projections, and purchasing plans to minimize third-party risks when selecting solutions
*   Implement solutions
*   Develop and implement processes to ensure solutions are installed securely and perform as intended.

> The ACT 1 Prize Program will prioritize utilities eligible to participate in the RMUC Program that have                       
> limited cybersecurity resources or serve military installations. Utilities are strongly encouraged to apply if                       
> they: (1) have limited economic and staff resources; (2) have limited access to cybersecurity training, TA,                       
> and support services; and (3) have a low cybersecurity maturity level.  Utilities that serve military                       
> installations are also strongly encouraged to apply.

Successful utilities in the ACT 1 Prize Program competition will **identify cybersecurity risks**, **identify solutions** that **reduce or eliminate** those risks, and **implement selected solutions**. Work completed by these utilities should accomplish one or more of the following goals: 

*   A) Increase a utility’s ability to identify cybersecurity threats within their information technology (IT) and operational technology (OT) systems Page 8 of 45
*   B) Improve a utility’s ability to protect against cybersecurity threats
*   C) Improve a utility’s ability to detect cybersecurity events and incidents soon after they occur
*   D) Prepare a utility to respond to and mitigate damage from a cybersecurity incident rapidly and effectively
*   E) Recover from a cybersecurity incident and identify and implement process improvements.

> Phase 1: Commitment. **Competitors will describe their utility’s need for assistance, the communities they serve**, and their **commitment to improving their utility’s cybersecurity posture**. The **50 limited cybersecurity resource** utilities and 5 utilities serving military installations that most successfully describe and demonstrate their cybersecurity needs, capacity to work with TA providers, and leadership commitment to the Program will be selected to win a Commitment Prize. Only utilities that have won a Commitment Prize are eligible to enter the Planning Phase and compete for a Planning Prize.

#### **General Eligibility Requirements**

> **The ACT 1 Prize Program competition is open only to eligible utilities** as defined in the RMUC Program’s authorizing legislation. 5 The following entities are eligible to compete in the ACT 1 Prize Program: 
> 
> *   Rural electric cooperatives
> *   Utilities owned by a political subdivision of a state, such as a municipally owned electric utility
> *   Utilities owned by any agency, authority, corporation, or instrumentality of one or more political subdivisions of a state
> *   Investor-owned electric utilities that sell less than 4,000,000 megawatt hours of electricity per year.
> 
> To be successful in competing in the LIMITED CYBERSECURITY RESOURCES track, a utility **must demonstrate that they have limited cybersecurity resources** in their submission package.

#### Specific Eligibility Requirements for Each Phase

>  Phase 1: Commitment: Eligibility 
> 
> *   A single utility may submit only one submission package on behalf of their eligible utility.
> *   The utility’s submission package must be complete.
> *   Each competitor must attend two mandatory virtual ACT 1 Prize workshops (See Section 1.3.6 for additional information.).

#### The following persons and entities are not eligible to compete in the ACT 1 Prize Program.

*   **DOE employees, employees of sponsoring organizations, members of their immediate families**                  
    (e.g., spouses, children, siblings, or parents), and persons living in the same household as such                  
    persons, whether or not related, are not eligible to participate in this prize contest.
*   Individuals who worked at DOE (federal employees or support service contractors) **within 6 months**                 
    **prior** to the submission deadline of any contest are not eligible to participate in any prize contests                  
    in this program.
*   **Federal entities and federal employees** are not eligible to participate in any portion of the prize.
*   **DOE national laboratory employees** cannot compete in the prize.
*   Entities and individuals publicly banned from doing business with the U.S. government such as                  
    entities and individuals debarred, suspended, or otherwise excluded from or ineligible for                  
    participating in federal programs are not eligible to compete.
*   Entities and individuals identified as a restricted party on one or more screening lists of the U.S.                  
    Departments of Commerce, State, and the Treasury are not eligible to compete. See Consolidated                  
    Screening List.
*   **Individuals participating in a foreign government talent recruitment program1** sponsored by a                  
    country of risk2 and teams that include such individuals are not eligible to compete.
*   **Entities owned by, controlled by, or subject to the jurisdiction or direction of a government of a**                 
    **country of risk are not eligible to compete**.

### Legal / Security

1.  Care must be taken not to submit sensitive details to the submissions process.
2.  Some risk is being created by the information that HeroX collects.
3.  It would be good to have a Legal Council review the following TOS documents.

#### A.9 Liability

> **Upon registration, all participants agree to assume any and all risks of injury or loss in connection with or**               
> **in any way arising from participation in this contest.** Upon registration, except in the case of willful               
> misconduct, all participants agree to and thereby do waive and release any and all claims or causes of               
> action against the federal government and its officers, employees, and agents for any and all injury and               
> damage of any nature whatsoever (whether existing or thereafter arising, whether direct, indirect, or               
> consequential, and whether foreseeable or not), arising from their participation in the contest, whether               
> the claim or cause of action arises under contract or tort.               
> In accordance with the delegation of authority to run this contest delegated to the judge responsible for               
> this prize, the judge has determined that no liability insurance naming DOE as an insured will be required               
> of competitors to compete in this competition per 15 U.S.C. § 3719(i)(2). Competitors should assess the               
> risks associated with their proposed activities and adequately insure themselves against possible losses.

#### A.10 Records Retention and Freedom of Information Act

> All materials submitted to DOE as part of a submission become DOE records and are subject to the               
> Freedom of Information Act. The following applies only to portions of the submission not designated as               
> public information in the instructions for submission. If a submission includes trade secrets or               
> information that is commercial or financial, or information that is confidential or privileged, it is furnished               
> to the government in confidence with the understanding that the information shall be used or disclosed               
> only for evaluation of the application. Such information will be withheld from public disclosure to the               
> extent permitted by law, including the Freedom of Information Act. Without assuming any liability for               
> inadvertent disclosure, DOE will seek to limit disclosure of such information to its employees and to               
> outside reviewers when necessary for review of the application or as otherwise authorized by law. This               
> restriction does not limit the government’s right to use the information if it is obtained from another               
> source.               
> Submissions containing confidential, proprietary, or privileged information must be marked as described               
> below. Failure to comply with these marking requirements may result in the disclosure of the unmarked               
> information under the Freedom of Information Act or otherwise. The U.S. government is not liable for the               
> disclosure or use of unmarked information and may use or disclose such information for any purpose.               
> The submission must be marked as follows and identify the specific pages containing trade secrets,               
> confidential, proprietary, or privileged information: “Notice of Restriction on Disclosure and Use of Data:               
> Pages \[list applicable pages\] of this document may contain trade secrets, confidential, proprietary, or               
> privileged information that is exempt from public disclosure. Such information shall be used or disclosed               
> only for evaluation purposes. \[End of Notice\]”               
> **The header and footer of every page that contains confidential, proprietary, or privileged information must**               
> **be marked as follows: “Contains Trade Secrets, Confidential, Proprietary, or Privileged Information Exempt**               
> **from Public Disclosure.”** In addition, each line or paragraph containing proprietary, privileged, or trade               
> secret information must be clearly marked with double brackets.               
> Competitors will be notified of any Freedom of Information Act requests for their submissions in               
> accordance with 10 C.F.R. Part 1004. Competitors may then have the opportunity to review materials and                
> Page 44 of 45               
> work with a Freedom of Information Act representative prior to the release of materials. DOE does intend               
> to keep all submission materials private except for those materials designated as “will be made public.”               
> IIJA §40124 (e) Protection of Information, states that information provided to, or collected by, the federal               
> government pursuant to this section the disclosure of which the Secretary reasonably foresees could be               
> detrimental to the physical security or cybersecurity of any electric utility or the bulk-power system:
> 
> (1) Shall be exempt from disclosure under section 552(b)(3) of title 5, United States Code
> 
> (2) Shall not be made available by any Federal agency, State, political subdivision of a State, or Tribal authority pursuant to any Federal, State, political subdivision of a State, or Tribal law, respectively, requiring public disclosure of information or records.

### HeroX Registration

> All utilities interested in competing in the ACT 1 Prize Program will need to create an account using the                   
> [HeroX](https://www.herox.com/ACT1Prize) website and then submit required materials to that account. **Each utility will be responsible** for                   
> uploading all required materials into HeroX before the deadline associated with each of the ACT 1 Prize                   
> phases.

#### [https://www.herox.com/privacy-policy](https://www.herox.com/privacy-policy) 

> **What We Collect**
> 
> Information You Give Us. We collect information you directly give us on our Site, like: your name, email address, password, location, education history, and work history.
> 
> Information We Get from Others. We may get information about you from other sources like social networking services you choose to connect with our services. We may add this to information we get from this Site.
> 
> Information Automatically Collected. We automatically log information about you and your computer. For example, when you visit our Site we log your computer's operating system, Internet Protocol (IP) address, access times, browser type and language, and the website you visited before coming to our Site are logged automatically. We also log information about your use of and actions on our Site.                  
>  
> 
> **Use of Personal Information**
> 
> We use your personal information to:
> 
> *   operate and improve our Site, services, and marketing;
> *   provide you with a personalized and customized experience;
> *   respond to your comments and questions and provide customer service;

You may also connect to, and share your information on, third party websites and services. Please be mindful of your own privacy needs as you choose who to connect with and what to share and make public. We cannot control the privacy or security of information you choose to make public or share with others.
> 
> **We do not share personal information with companies, organizations and individuals outside of HeroX unless one of the following circumstances applies:**
> 
> *   We may share personal information with your consent. For example, you may let us share personal information with others for their own campaigns, events, and marketing uses through participating in challenges. Those uses will be subject to their privacy policies.
> *   **We may share personal information when we do a business deal, or negotiate a business deal, involving sale or transfer of all or a part of our business or assets**. These deals can include any merger, financing, acquisition, or bankruptcy transaction or proceeding.
> *   We may share personal information for legal, protection and safety purposes.
> *   We may share information to comply with laws.
> *   We may share information to respond to lawful requests and legal process.
> *   **We may share information to protect the rights and property of HeroX, our agents, customers, and others. This includes enforcing our agreements, policies and terms of use.**
> *   We may share information in an emergency. This includes protecting the safety of our employees and agents, our customers, or any person.
> *   We may share information with those who do work for us.
> *   **We may also share aggregate and deidentified data with others.**

#### [https://www.herox.com/cookie-policy](https://www.herox.com/cookie-policy)

Boiler Plate

#### [https://www.herox.com/community-guidelines](https://www.herox.com/community-guidelines)

Boiler Plate

Phase 2 Planning
----------------

> Phase 2. Planning: utilities work with TA providers to: complete technical assessments of their                       
> systems; identify areas where training would improve staff skills and abilities; gain a better                       
> understanding of potential risks and solutions; identify solutions to address prioritized risks;                       
> and draft a roadmap for implementation.

*   Submission Due Aug 2024
*   Identify risks, prioritize solutions, and draft roadmap
*   Prize Awarded to ~30 winners ~Oct 2024
*   Award: $50k / 60 hours Technical Assistance

> Competitors will be expected to complete assessments, provide justifications for proposed solutions, and develop estimated budgets for implementation of their roadmaps. In addition, competitors will draft a [Section 40126 Cybersecurity Plan](https://www.energy.gov/ceser/bipartisan-infrastructure-law-implementation). 

Phase 3 Implementation
----------------------

> Phase 3. Implementation: utilities make substantial progress toward completing their roadmap.

*   Submission Due Jan 2025
*   Finalize and make progress on roadmap
*   Prize Awarded to ~30 winners ~Oct 2024
*   Award: $100k

To: Amani Reddy <areddy1@alaska.edu>, Andy Aschwanden <aaschwanden@alaska.edu>, Billy Connor <bgconnor@alaska.edu>, Brandon Briggs <bbriggs6@alaska.edu>, Carl Tape <ctape@alaska.edu>, Christopher Pike <cpike6@alaska.edu>, David Fee <dfee1@alaska.edu>, Don Hampton <dhampton@alaska.edu>, Falk Huettmann <fhuettmann@alaska.edu>, Frank Witmer <fwitmer@alaska.edu>, Jessica Glass <jrglass@alaska.edu>, Katherine Hedstrom <kshedstrom@alaska.edu>, Liam Forbes <loforbes@alaska.edu>, Masoumeh Heidari Kapourchali <mheidari2@alaska.edu>, Matthew Kupilik <mkupilik@alaska.edu>, Michael West <mewest@alaska.edu>, Misha Chakraborty <mchakraborty@alaska.edu>, Nibedita Sinha <nsinha3@alaska.edu>, Nima Farzadnia <nfarzadnia@alaska.edu>, Obadare Awoleke <ooawoleke@alaska.edu>, Orion Lawlor <oslawlor@alaska.edu>, Sampurna Arya <snarya@alaska.edu>, Seth Danielson <sldanielson@alaska.edu>, Subhabrata Dev <sdev@alaska.edu>, Vikas Sonwalkar <vssonwalkar@alaska.edu>
Cc: INE P&P Office <uaf-ine-pp@alaska.edu>, Sandra Boatwright <sboatwright@alaska.edu>, William Schnabel <weschnabel@alaska.edu>, Nettie La Belle-Hamer <nettie.labellehamer@alaska.edu>, Jon Genetti <jdgenetti@alaska.edu>, Dayne Broderson <dbbroderson@alaska.edu>, Julie Benson <jcbenson@alaska.edu>, Diane O'Brien <dmobrien@alaska.edu>, Richard Collins <rlcollins@alaska.edu>, Chu, Kelvin <kchu@tigdc.com>, <uaf-ogca@alaska.edu>, UAF OGCA Pre-Award <uaf-ogca-preaward@alaska.edu>


Dear All Collaborators of NSF-MRI grant,

CONGRATULATIONS!!!! 

We have received the funding (approx. $910K USD) for our proposal titled 'Equipment: MRI Track-I: Acquisition of CyBR: Cyber Infrastructure for Big Data Research Critical for Alaska'. 

My sincere thanks to all the twenty four co-authors from both UAF and UAA who contributed to the proposal with their thoughtful research/education ideas. As a PI of the proposal I really hope that this instrument will help advance all your research activities. I believe this instrumentation will be a major driver for the University of Alaska (UA) Statewide System to pursue research activities that are really critical for Alaska's wellbeing, especially those which are data-intensive and/or computationally challenging. I also hope this It will play a major role in improving the UA system's technology education infrastructure contributing significantly towards building the state's future hitech workforce.

My sincere THANKS to the INE proposal office, OGCA, tam and the proposal offices of each collaborator for preparing the budget, budget-justification, review work, and other activities that made the submission process meticulously correct and smooth. A very special THANK to Sandra Boatwright who is retired now but led the entire effort even on her last day at work when NSF asked for the updated CPOSs from all the Co-PIs and Senior Personnel.

My sincere thanks to Kelvin Chu and his TIG team for reviewing my proposal before submission and suggesting the modifications that ended up in a successful award.

Finally, I would also like to thank all the Deans, Directors, and VCR for their support starting from white paper competition, its selection, and providing all the prerequisites including the research environments, labs, contacts, letters of support, and other administrative support. 

In the end, as a second year Assistant Professor at UAF (about to submit my last year documents in Faculty 180 😆 ), I would like to express my sincere THANKS to you all for supporting me as a PI and contributing to the proposal. I really appreciate all your efforts. IT REALLY MEANS A LOT.

I will update the project status from time to time and will organize meetings with you to decide the next steps. 

Thanks and Regards,
Arghya Kusum Das,

subject: Github TOS
description:
Has ACEP Reviewed Github TOS for Federal Agencies?

**Terms of Service**  
 

From a 2023-02-13 email I sent to CFOS students

> Specifically for CFOS,  
> A few points to consider before using [github.com](http://github.com/) for University related repositories:
> 
> 1.  Do not publish content on  public repositories unless you have prior permission from the [UA Office of Intellectual Property](https://www.uaf.edu/oipc/) to do so.
> 2.  READ the [Terms of service](https://docs.github.com/en/site-policy/github-terms/github-terms-of-service) to make sure your project is in compliance.  There are many legal things to consider.
> 3.  READ the additional [ToS for U.S. Federal Government](https://docs.github.com/en/site-policy/site-policy-deprecated/amendment-to-github-terms-of-service-applicable-to-us-federal-government-users) users if your project is federally funded.
> 4.  Be careful when creating non-UA accounts on external vendor sites ([github.com](http://github.com/))  It maybe more advisable to contact OIT about using UA's Github server:   [https://github.alaska.edu/](https://github.alaska.edu/)   (This also mostly addresses business continuity, ToS and other security concerns.)
> 
>   
> Git is a powerful tool for managing code bases.  I highly recommend using Git.    
> GitHub is a private company and care must be taken before posting code to it for both legal and cybersecurity reasons.     
> GitHub is not equivalent to Git.  Oftentimes people confuse them.  
> Also for the brave, you can host you one git server with [Gitea](https://gitea.io/en-us/)

**UA Github**

We have [github.alaska.edu](http://github.alaska.edu/) linked to our @[alaska.edu](http://alaska.edu/) accounts.   However this resource is for UA use only and not for publishing or collaborating outside of UA.  While this service is still online I've heard it will be going away but don't have a hard ETA on this.  I used to use this to internally host SKQ repos: [https://github.alaska.edu/skq](https://github.alaska.edu/skq)  However have move all of those repositories over to [https://ci.sikuliaq.alaska.edu/git/skqit](https://ci.sikuliaq.alaska.edu/git/skqit)  (Self hosted) to avoid getting cut off when [github.alaska.edu](http://github.alaska.edu/) goes away.

I've reached out to Liam Forbes (RCS) to see if he knows more about the status of this and what is the prefered UAF Github resource.  Standing by for a response.

**Office of Intellectual Property**

Per a contract letter I recently signed:

> Ownership of intellectual property you may produce is governed by University [Regulation 10.07.05](https://www.alaska.edu/bor/policy-regulations/chapter-10-07-research-scholarship-creative-activity.php#P10.07.050) or, if  
> applicable, the terms of a collective bargaining agreement.

My interpretation of this has been that I'm not at liberty to share code or works that UAF paid me to produce with those outside of UAF without prior permission.

There may be some exceptions if we receive grant funding for the purposes of collaboration with persons outside of UAF. 

I would advise contacting the UAF Office of Intellectual Property and Commercialization [https://www.uaf.edu/oipc/](https://www.uaf.edu/oipc/) to get that permission.  
 

FYI I did work with UAF OIPC to license the ITAM project so that I could share it with others in the fleet.  It was a fairly easy process of proposing and ISC license and getting written permission to publish this codebase.

*   [https://www.sikuliaq.alaska.edu/git/skq/skq-it-am](https://www.sikuliaq.alaska.edu/git/skq/skq-it-am)

**If you get their permission in writing then it clear sailing to share code and works from there on.**

**Open Source License**

Choice of license is important.  I strongly recommend that any work use a permissive license such as:

*   [MIT](https://opensource.org/license/MIT/)
*   [BSD 3 Clause](https://opensource.org/license/bsd-3-clause/)
*   [ISC](https://opensource.org/license/isc-license-txt/)

I advise against restrictive or wordy licenses such at GPL or Apache.

subject: Haverlack Bio
description:
**Bio**

John studied physics at [Virginia Tech](https://www.vt.edu/) in the early '90s and taught high school [STEM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Science%2C_technology%2C_engineering%2C_and_mathematics) in [central](https://svgs.k12.va.us/) and [western](https://ahs.ahps.k12.va.us/) Virginia for ~5 years. Since 1991, he has been a Linux administrator and even played a role in installing the first [Linux](http://www.slackware.com/) system at Virginia Tech. Professionally, he has worked in the private sector for companies such as [Transmeta, Inc](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmeta), and [Sourceforge, Inc](https://sourceforge.net/). John came to [UAF](https://www.uaf.edu/uaf/) in 2002, initially with the [Alaska Satellite Facility](https://asf.alaska.edu/).   Since 2009, he has served as the IT manager for the UAF [College of Fisheries and Ocean Sciences](https://www.uaf.edu/cfos/).  There he has been intimately involved in the design, deployment and maintenance of cyberinfrastructure onboard the [R/V _Sikuliaq_](https://www.uaf.edu/cfos/sikuliaq/). Parallel to his _Sikuliaq_ role, John has also been a consultant to the [U.S. Academic Research Fleet](https://www.unols.org/) assisting with the development of a new cybersecurity program. In his spare time, John pursues interest in [physics](https://wolframphysics.org/visual-summary/dark/), [decentralized technologies](https://appliedbitlogistics.io/podci/), and dabbles in amateur woodworking and an offgrid solar energy project around his home in Fairbanks Alaska. Whenever possible he enjoys road tripping around the state with his partner Nicole Stewart.

subject: Quick question - A.I. notetaking (Patty Eagan
description:
Hi John, (I sit in that back area by you, but work remotely some times)

Since you're a security and technology guru.. quick question! (No worries if this is not your wheelhouse)

Do you know if UAF has guidance about the A.I.-linked bot accounts that join Zoom meetings sometimes? We precautiously have been removing them from ACEP-hosted meetings since it was new and folks wanted to learn more before accepting everything AI was noting on our internal meetings.

For context, I help host monthly hydrogen energy working group meetings with a wide variety of non-UAF folks, so would like to respect others while following UAF protocols since it's a UAF hosted meeting.

Thank you,

Patty  
 

\--

Patty Eagan  _(she/her)_

_Project Coordinator_

Alaska Center for Energy and Power ([ACEP](http://acep.uaf.edu/))

University of Alaska Fairbanks  
 

[pmeagan@alaska.edu](mailto:pmeagan@alaska.edu)  |  c: (907) 322-4793

_I live and work on the traditional territories of the lower Tanana Dené Athabascan Peoples._

[_Subscribe to ACEP's Newsletter for Stories and Events_](https://www.uaf.edu/acep/news/index.php)

subject: Do we want ACEP to participate in UAF Sponsored CISA Vulnerablity Scanning?
description:
Hi John - We'll be engaging with DHS/CISA to perform a risk and vulnerability assessment (RVA) in July.  It's a two-week engagement half remote and half on-site.  I'd like to include Sikuliaq's public IP space in the assessment but wanted to check with you first.  Do you have any concerns?  One of the team conducting this assessment serves in the Navy and is familiar with shipboard OT/IT.  I've asked them if they've specifically conducted any pentests or vuln. scans against operating ships at sea and am waiting to hear back.

Would you like to chat further?  I'm happy to schedule a Zoom meeting or if you're in Fairbanks we can chat in-person.  I need to get the scoping document sent back to them in about two weeks so let's talk before if possible.  The attached slide deck will provide a little more detail on the engagement.

Thanks!

Sean

subject: RAISE: CET: FEDORA Project Review
description:
RAISE: CET: Fostering Energy Data Operational Resilience in Alaska (FEDORA)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

[https://docs.google.com/document/d/1JzY-oMtwX8JzLtzdoLkvkrG\_mR\_nWONkrqBCvKhtpmU/edit](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1JzY-oMtwX8JzLtzdoLkvkrG_mR_nWONkrqBCvKhtpmU/edit)

*   Duration: 2 years | Requested Budget: $999,327 | PI: Dr. Daisy Huang, co-I: Dr. Frank Witmer

> This research develops and tests strategies for training a workforce in data and cybersecurity in the clean energy sector by focusing on data from or related to energy systems in remote and hub communities in Alaska

*   distributed energy resources (DERs) 
*   independent (IPPs)
*   virtual power producers (VPPs)
*   UAF-ACEP Beneficial Equitable Electrification Home InnoVation Experiment (BEEhive)
*   UAF-ACEP Advanced Metering Infrastructure - Cyber Physical Platform (AMI-CP)

> **This research pilots and tests solutions to education and workforce needs (topic F) in the Alaskan energy data sector through training and mentorship in cyberinfrastructure, cybersecurity, and creating a culture of best practices that stimulate a robust data ecosystem by seeking support from Directorate for STEM Education (EDU) and Computer and Information Science and Engineering (CISE).**

**FEDORA values**

*   Place-based and experiential learning
*   Hands on / real world application: learn by doing
*   Ethical frameworks and relationship-maintaining responsibilities at the heart of data work
*   Respect for and support of Indigenous sovereignty and self-determination
*   Data is essential to good decision making and tackling complex problems of the future

subject: Reporting requirement: Due October 20 - Eco Devo projects (ops/capital)
description:
Greetings,

In July UA President Pitney, in coordination with UAF leadership, scheduled a discussion with the ACEP leadership regarding the economic development projects. ACEP received operating (unrestricted) and capital funds (G14957) starting July 1, 2022. We have been asked to provide regular updates to the system office and UAF leadership including:

A brief update (list) of your accomplishments since July 1, 2023

Indicate if you are on-track to meet your milestones as outlined in the [July reporting](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1GEfLjR3_rY0XangroNdt4DyYLLkGSST78KkLP2xLLE4/edit?usp=sharing).

Please provide your update via [this link](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1LFMpuziXFFauWcHzxHXVCN4TIJDBFydo36WMBFiHi9o/edit?usp=sharing) by **Friday, October 20**.   
Please let me know if you have any questions ASAP.

Thank you,

Jennifer

subject: ioninja ethernet tap
description:
John,

The ioninja device can be found here:

[https://ioninja.com/](https://ioninja.com/)

In particular, we have the very basic ethernet tap and no additional modules.

[https://ioninja.com/hardware/ethernet-tap.html](https://ioninja.com/hardware/ethernet-tap.html)

It is quite an upgrade to wireshark. It will export pcap logs that can be later used in wireshark if that is a preferred workflow. The amount of extra modules is a bit staggering.

Rob
---

Rob Cermak (cermak@alaska.edu)

subject: Guide to Operational Technology (OT) Security: NIST Publishes SP 800-82, Revision 3
description:
Notes
-----

[https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/ics/](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/ics/)
