subject: Github Enterprise Questions
description:
> John will revisit Dayne request after Nov 4th:  Having a GitHub enterprise ACEP org that uses our UA-provided identities could be an excellent tool to address some of the risks he is identifying (or will identify)  in some of our processes and protocols around code & data management. 

Travis and John,

I am looping John into this email thread from _two years (yikes)_ ago because this is a thread I want him to be aware of as he is getting his bearings in his new role at ACEP as our Cybersecurity lead.

Having a GitHub enterprise ACEP org that uses our UA-provided identities could be an excellent tool to address some of the risks he is identifying (or will identify)  in some of our processes and protocols around code & data management. 

\-dayne

On Wed, Jul 13, 2022, 11:38 AM Dayne Broderson <[dayne@alaska.edu](mailto:dayne@alaska.edu)\> wrote:   
 

> Travis,
> 
> This was not TLDR.  This was an amazingly detailed and coherent run down.  I will need to read/re-read with a clean brain to properly digest and reply .. which is not a today thing but I want to make sure you know I super appreciate this detailed response with detailed options.  I'll loop back with you later this month with a cleaner set of next steps.
> 
> We do have funding to cover costs of this but I need to coordinate with Jennifer, our executive officer, to understand how we might stage the invoices so we can then split the costs appropriately between different grants.
> 
> Best,
> 
> \-dayne
> 
> On Tue, Jul 12, 2022 at 10:51 PM Travis Payton <[tpayton1@alaska.edu](mailto:tpayton1@alaska.edu)\> wrote:   
>  
> 
> > Also, related to compliance,  we do have access to a number of reports we can share if needed as well:
> > 
> > ![image.png](https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0?ui=2&ik=598cc1f026&attid=0.1&permmsgid=msg-f:1780141582805035376&th=18b4555684fee970&view=fimg&fur=ip&sz=s0-l75-ft&attbid=ANGjdJ8qNO9ei-th-bZgaJ_YYXOEmZ1tuAWDbtmjymtELwEpXEV4hvJtC80GnIZA_FASFfRJ2uqaRBDp4CBCX_JcXx7jBgp5F748wcxgIt8R-ABjWEgDdMM8Baajz4w&disp=emb&realattid=ii_l5j8t6ia0)
> > 
> > Thanks,
> > 
> > Travis Payton   
> > Sr. Engineering Manager
> > 
> > OIT Platforms, Applications, & Web Services
> > 
> > Butrovich 105E
> > 
> > 907-474-2621
> > 
> > On Tue, Jul 12, 2022 at 10:38 PM Travis Payton <[tpayton1@alaska.edu](mailto:tpayton1@alaska.edu)\> wrote:   
> >  
> > 
> > > Hi Dayne,
> > > 
> > > I'll try and answer these questions, however I feel this will quickly turn into a TLDR so I'll start by saying we can work with you to get billing setup for LFS for your Orgs (do you have a Fund/Org?), and you can manage your Org however you need to in order to meet your Security requirements.  Related to Git LFS, I wrote a [fork of Git-fat](https://github.com/ua-oit-se/git-fat) that works with Google-Drive if you want a free alternative.  Related to a Cybersecurity POC, if you need someone to be a second pair of eyes on the NDA and security requirements I would recommend Shiva Hullavard or Jeannette Okinczyc or Sean Hagan.
> > > 
> > > With that out of the way here is the long answer :)
> > > 
> > > Our team (OIT Platforms, Applications, & Web Services) manages the Enterprise Github service for UA including the contract with Github. Our campus is part of the Github Campus program, and so we get Github Enterprise Server and Github Enterprise Cloud for free as long as we agree and follow the terms of the program.  Part of those terms say we act as a single point of contact for Github and answer technical questions from our users.
> > > 
> > > The best way I can think to explain how the Github Enterprise Cloud works is to break it down into it's various scopes.  The largest scope that we manage is the Enterprise Account.  We have been given a single Github Enterprise account ([https://github.com/enterprises/university-of-alaska](https://github.com/enterprises/university-of-alaska)).  Within the Enterprise Account you have 2 roles: Enterprise Owner and Enterprise Billing Manager.  Enterprise Owners are just like Org Owners except for the Enterprise. Enterprise Owners can do things such as create/invite Organizations, and set overarching policies that apply to every Org in the Enterprise such as requiring SAML auth in addition to Github Auth or requiring 2 Factor authentication.  Currently, a subset of OIT PAWS (and Mike Brase) are the Enterprise Owners, and we require all of our members who have access to manage the Enterprise Account to have 2 Factor on their Github account.  There is also an audit log for every action related to Enterprise Management, Org Management, Team Management, Repo Management, Web Hooks, etc that we can query and export for everything under the Enterprise Account.
> > > 
> > > The next scope is Orgs.  When an Org is created under the Enterprise Account, or is invited to join the Enterprise Account,  then any member of that Org automatically becomes a member of the Enterprise.  By default, whoever creates the Org will be an Org owner,  but after the Organization is handed over to the department or team that requested it they can then manage that Org including all of it's settings (including SAML and 2 factor) and it's members.  Enterprise Owners can see every Org that is part of the Enterprise Account regardless of whether or not they are a member of that Org.  Recently, Github added the ability for Enterprise Owners to add themselves as an owner of an Enterprise Org, but this is something we only do when requested by the Org owner.
> > > 
> > > Now the fun part,  Github.com has not really had what we would call traditional IAM until very recently (see Enterprise Managed Users further down).  Traditionally Github has offered only two ways for users to authenticate into Github Enterprise Cloud:
> > > 
> > > *   [Authentication through GitHub.com](https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identity-and-access-management/managing-iam-for-your-enterprise/about-authentication-for-your-enterprise#authentication-through-githubcom) or
> > > *   [Authentication through GitHub.com with additional SAML access restriction](https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identity-and-access-management/managing-iam-for-your-enterprise/about-authentication-for-your-enterprise#authentication-through-githubcom-with-additional-saml-access-restriction)
> > > 
> > > By default, each Org member must create a personal account on GitHub.com. As long as they are a member of an Org that is a part of our Enterprise, they are a member of our Enterprise and can access other Enterprise resources that are scoped to Internal.  If you add SAML authentication to your Org, when an org member signs in with their Github.com account, they will then be forced to sign in via the configured IdP using SAML and link their Github account to an identity in the IdP.  This is useful if user management is critical for an Org and you want people to lose access to the Org as soon as they lose access to other services behind the IdP.  It does make other things more difficult though such as requiring users to reauthenticate to the IdP every 24 hours and authorizing SSH keys and access tokens.  More info can be found [here](https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/organizations/managing-saml-single-sign-on-for-your-organization/about-identity-and-access-management-with-saml-single-sign-on).
> > > 
> > > The last scope would be Repos.  As you're probably well aware, each repo can have it's own members and permissions and settings, and the visibility can be set to Public, Internal, or Private.  (Internal means other Enterprise members can see it.)  You can also invite Outside Collaborators to a repo.  Outside collaborators do not become a member of the repo or of the Enterprise, and are not subject to any SAML access restriction that might be configured on the Org.  
> > > 
> > > Github has only recommended organizations require members to create a new Github.com account specifically for the Org / Enterprise if they need to minimize risk of developers _accidentally_ pushing valuable data to another Org or Gist outside of the Enterprise.  If the Enterprise's developers are trusted, then the recommendation is to use personal Github accounts so users can get the attributions and stats that come with doing work such as commits, pull requests, and merges.   Once a user's account is no longer a member of an Enterprise Org, they will lose access to all of the Enterprise's resources, but they will still have the stats of how many commits they have done for example.  On each Org the user can also configure what email and name should be used,  so even though my Github.com personal account is Sutekidayo, on every UA Enterprise Org I use Travis Payton and [tpayton1@alaska.edu](mailto:tpayton1@alaska.edu) for attribution and notifications.  The most flexibility we have to automate user provisioning is to send Org invites via an API call to email addresses.  However, a user must still have or create a Github.com account in order to accept the invite.
> > > 
> > > Github has recently released a third authentication option called [Github Enterprise Managed Users](https://docs.github.com/en/enterprise-cloud@latest/admin/identity-and-access-management/using-enterprise-managed-users-for-iam/about-enterprise-managed-users).  It only supports Azure AD and Okta, and the ODIC account management is still in Beta and only for Azure AD currently.  Enterprise Managed Users are exactly what they sound like -- they are basically a super restricted Github.com account that we can provision and manage, but they can only be a member of an Enterprise's Orgs and can only access repos within the Enterprise's orgs.  The downside is it is either all or nothing. If we want to use Managed Users we will need to contact sales and migrate to a new Github Enterprise Account.  Also, a Github Enterprise Account that is using Managed Users can not have any public repos. Everything must be Private or Internal.
> > > 
> > > Due to the nature of our Enterprise Account being used by Students, Staff, and Faculty for a wide range of things, we refrain from setting restrictive policies on the Enterprise Account level and recommend the more restrictive settings be handled on an org-by-org basis.  If you would like to get SAML setup on your Org(s), we can assist with that.   
> > > 
> > > One last thing to note is last time I was reviewing security standards for ACUASI I discovered that Github Enterprise Cloud is not authorized for ITAR data, but a properly hosted Github Enterprise Server is.  I don't believe UA OIT could host ITAR data as we employ non-US citizens such as permanent residents and some student employees, but if you would like to host your own Github Enterprise Server we can provide you with a license as well.     
> > >  
> > > 
> > > Hopefully that all makes sense.  Let me know what other questions you have now as well. :)
> > > 
> > > Thanks,
> > > 
> > > Travis Payton   
> > > Sr. Engineering Manager
> > > 
> > > OIT Platforms, Applications, & Web Services
> > > 
> > > Butrovich 105E
> > > 
> > > 907-474-2621
> > > 
> > > On Tue, Jul 12, 2022 at 5:34 PM Dayne Broderson <[dayne@alaska.edu](mailto:dayne@alaska.edu)\> wrote:   
> > >  
> > > 
> > > > Walker, Travis, Doug, and Mike,
> > > > 
> > > > I am working through some questions about if ACEP can use our GitHub Cloud Enterprise account as a place to manage some critical energy infrastructure information provided to us under an NDA.
> > > > 
> > > > Given that GitHub Cloud Enterprise accounts are FedRAMP authorized (P-ATO) I would say the answer is yes as long as we've got a good handle as University of Alaska on our management of our GitHub.
> > > > 
> > > > A few things jump out to me as likely needing review and clean-up at the organizational level: 
> > > > 
> > > > *   Admin information is currently: [doug.knight@karmix.org](mailto:doug.knight@karmix.org)   
> > > >     That should be a @alaska.edu identity.
> > > > *   There are  7 organization admins currently listed:   
> > > >     [https://github.com/orgs/acep-uaf/people/enterprise\_owners](https://github.com/orgs/acep-uaf/people/enterprise_owners)   
> > > >     That should be reviewed for any updates/clean-up needed.
> > > > *   I need to know who is the right POC to talk to about expanding our GitHub LFS quota and paying for that.    
> > > >     We are currently using 2.1GB of 1GB of our github LFS quota and I would like to expand that usage significantly but want to understand how to handle any possible costs that will be triggered when I do that.
> > > > *   Who is the right cybersecurity POC who could help us review and play the UA system role in our system security plan for our GitHub platform?
> > > > 
> > > > Best,
> > > > 
> > > > \-dayne
> > > > 
> > > > \--   
> > > >  
> > > > 
> > > > [dayne@alaska.edu](mailto:dayne@alaska.edu) | 907-590-1066 | [acep.uaf.edu](http://acep.uaf.edu/)   
> > > >  
> 
> \--   
>  
> 
> [dayne@alaska.edu](mailto:dayne@alaska.edu) | 907-590-1066 | [acep.uaf.edu](http://acep.uaf.edu/)

subject: Railbelt Innovative Resiliency Project
description:
Dayne,

John,

 

In our recent conversations we spoke about resiliency and BESS projects, but we did not focus on the RIR nor did we speak to the GRIP Program. We covered much ground, but I believe there was not enough time on the call.

 

Would it make sense to address this project in a focused call, specifically how we might be able to assist on a larger scale and perhaps even on the services side? We are a known quantity at Matanuska, however Homer, Seward, Golden Valley and Chugach also play a role here. We have partnerships lined up to address the NRECA ICS-REC program so this could fit nicely.

 

Looking forward to following up with both of you on this and to your feedback.

 

 

Best,

 

Christian

_____________

Christian Hager

subject: ACEP 2024 Internship Project - Energy Infosec Network Security
description:
> Proposed 3 possible ACEP Cybersecurity Internships: [Cybersecurity Awareness Training](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1SrLfuyzCTThNOeGDtpe3hLnT4aktrvkwHi67jccnpsA/edit#heading=h.4hcv1yuvxsd5), [Small Energy Utility Gap Assessment Template](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1hsGLV7pDHMdky8qswvcXnQeAQCWjpr6SAvYrYxtWQJM/edit#heading=h.ordjlhqrtk5r), [Simulink Energy Microgrid OT Network Simulation.](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1cXIq8RwKPumv5rEeqj7qhvYG4uBesSVJmTWfolLu46k/edit#heading=h.dwichmdc4v67)

See: [https://docs.google.com/document/d/1eUpMVAyToFcNies3EZwhatiYJFiKhvhgZftsyjVuZrw/edit](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1eUpMVAyToFcNies3EZwhatiYJFiKhvhgZftsyjVuZrw/edit)

#### Project Descriptions

[https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1uE4AND5Y5QzBZX3Owzv0X2X8mE8GBKqWVj\_HKYADR6K7bPUJaMDivYqo0MlP9mzbbva9mAsO](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1uE4AND5Y5QzBZX3Owzv0X2X8mE8GBKqWVj_HKYADR6K7bPUJaMDivYqo0MlP9mzbbva9mAsO)

*   Can we use Cybersecurity Funding?

### Internship 1:  

### Cybersecurity Awareness Training Modules

**Mentor:** [John Haverlack](https://www.uaf.edu/acep/about/our-team/john-haverlack.php)

**Location:** Fairbanks

**Key themes:** cybersecurity, video editing and production, storytelling

**Background:** 

**Project:** 

To develop a mini-series of modular **cybersecurity awareness training** presentations with accompanying training videos.   Each module will be developed with an accompanying presentation slide deck and training video such that the module can be presented in person or provided as a video to be shared for individual viewing.

*   Collaborate with the project mentor to identify and organize training modules and curriculum content.
*   Develop a presentation slide deck for each training module.  Likely using Google Docs or ODF format.
*   Develop or curate legally licensed graphics for use in the presentation.
*   Develop or curate legally licensed video content for the presentation.
*   All module content will be published with a liberal open source license to facilitate adoption by any organization.
*   Each module should be 15-30 minutes in length.
*   Video to be published on Youtube and possibly other platforms as appropriate.
*   Consideration for alternate media format that may target digital divide, ADA accessibility, or generational communications gaps.

Training modules may include:

*   Cybersecurity Awareness Basics
*   Handling Sensitive Information
*   Social Engineering
*   Cyber Hygiene and Security Tools
*   Digital Privacy Best Practices
*   Encrypting Data
*   Research Cybersecurity
*   Cybersecurity for Seniors
*   Introduction to Cybersecurity Compliance Frameworks
*   Network Security
*   Operational Security

**Field of Study / Skills:**

*   Strong written and verbal communication skills
*   Technical writing and story telling
*   Producing and editing video presentations
*   Video narration

**Type of Work:**

**Travel:**

**Mentorship Type:** In-person

#### Notes:

**Equipment:**

*   A laptop or desktop with 32 GB RAM, a 1 TB NVMe storage disk
*   Adobe PhotoShop and Premier for video editing and graphics design

### Internship 2: 

### Small Energy Utility Gap Assessment Template

**Mentor:** [John Haverlack](https://www.uaf.edu/acep/about/our-team/john-haverlack.php)

**Location:** Fairbanks

**Key themes:**

**Background:** 

In the rapidly evolving landscape of energy utilities, cybersecurity is a paramount concern. With the increasing reliance on digital technologies and operational technology (OT) systems, small energy utilities face unique challenges in securing their infrastructure. This project aims to develop a comprehensive gap assessment template that aligns with the Section 40126 Cybersecurity Plan, and integrates the principles of the NIST cybersecurity framework and NIST SP 800-82 Rev. 3 Guide to OT Security to help small energy utilities conduct cost effective initial cybersecurity assessments.

**Project:** 

**Objectives:**

**1\. Understanding Cybersecurity Frameworks and Standards:**

*   Gain a thorough understanding of the Section 40126 Cybersecurity Plan, NIST Cybersecurity Framework, and NIST SP 800-82 Rev. 3.
*   Analyze the specific requirements and guidelines outlined in these frameworks, focusing on their relevance to small energy utilities.

**2\. Gap Assessment Template Design:**

*   Design a comprehensive template that small energy utilities can use to assess their cybersecurity readiness and identify gaps in their current practices.
*   Ensure the template is user-friendly, adaptable, and scalable to different sizes and types of small energy utilities.

**3\. Integration of Cybersecurity Best Practices:**

*   Incorporate best practices for cybersecurity in energy utilities, with a focus on OT security.
*   Align the template with industry standards and regulatory requirements, ensuring it aids utilities in achieving compliance and enhancing security posture.

**4\. Validation and Testing:**

*   Develop a plan to test the effectiveness and usability of the template in real-world scenarios.
*   Collaborate with industry experts or relevant stakeholders for feedback and improvement suggestions.

**5\. Documentation and Training Material Development:**

*   Create comprehensive documentation that explains the usage of the template, including case studies or examples.
*   Develop training materials or guidelines to assist small energy utilities in implementing the gap assessment process.

**Expected Outcomes:**

*   A robust gap assessment template tailored for small energy utilities.
*   A set of documentation and training materials to support the implementation of the template.
*   Enhanced understanding of the cybersecurity landscape in the energy sector, particularly in relation to OT security.

**Field of Study / Skills:**

*   Knowledge of cybersecurity principles and frameworks, especially in relation to energy utilities.
*   Ability to analyze and synthesize complex information into practical tools and resources.
*   Strong communication and collaboration skills for stakeholder engagement.

**Type of Work:**

**Travel:**

**Mentorship Type:** In-person

### Internship 3: 

### Simulink Energy Microgrid OT Network Simulation

**Mentor:** [John Haverlack](https://www.uaf.edu/acep/about/our-team/john-haverlack.php)

mponent of the project involves the implementation of a SCADA (Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition) system within the simulation. This system will be tasked with monitoring and controlling the microgrid, creating an environment that closely resembles operational technology networks in the energy sector. Integral to this setup is the simulation of Modbus communication protocols, generating data streams that mimic those found in industrial control systems.

The cybersecurity aspect of the project is of paramount importance. The simulated environment will serve as a testing ground for detecting and analyzing potential cybersecurity threats to the microgrid. This involves developing and applying strategies to identify, analyze, and mitigate attacks, thereby enhancing the security posture of such critical infrastructure.

Further, the project involves comprehensive log collection and analysis. The intern will implement mechanisms to gather and scrutinize data from various components of the microgrid system. This analysis will not only aid in understanding the normal operations of the system but will also be pivotal in identifying any anomalies that could indicate security breaches or operational malfunctions.

Simulated data generated from this project will be use to generate machine learning training data, and to evaluate various advance cybersecurity services including:

SIEM - Security Information and Event Management    
IDS - Intrusion Detection Systems    
Centralized logging and log analysis    
The project encompasses developing simulated data for cybersecurity modeling and testing. Overall, this internship offers a unique opportunity to delve into the intersecting worlds of energy systems and cybersecurity, providing hands-on experience in a field that is increasingly critical in our technology-driven world.

Field of Study / Skills:

Knowledge of Simulink for modeling, simulating, and analyzing multidomain dynamical systems.    
Basic knowledge of energy systems, particularly in microgrids, including solar, wind, and diesel power generation.    
Experience in simulating network environments, specifically Operational Technology (OT) networks.    
Understanding of communication protocols like Modbus, commonly used in industrial control systems.    
Familiarity with advanced cybersecurity threat protection systems.    
Strong problem-solving abilities to develop solutions for complex systems and potential cybersecurity challenges.    
Analytical mindset to interpret data and draw meaningful conclusions from simulations.    
Willingness to learn new tools and technologies as the project evolves.    
Ability to adapt to changing project requirements and explore innovative solutions.    
Type of Work:

This project will primarily be centered around programming and developing Realtime Simulink models, but will also include a mix of other technical skill sets including networking, devops programming, and data acquisition.

Travel:

### Internship 4:

subject: Water at PNNL - National STEM Day - TORCH: Igniting the Future of Hydropower Cybersecurity
description:
> Contacted  [Penny McKenzie](https://info.pnnl.gov/e3t/Ctc/OI+113/c17Ms04/VVFJJS7zTV-HW60Gk837Hc4xfW67tPB755D2Y1N1k24Y23qgyTW6N1vHY6lZ3mdW8SFBG02QSPGrW73QvVQ7sjcwbW7C0H286krZw_W15F1SX8t2ZCKVmySBk1fLPVtW4Q4mDH1RbNQkW7BdKZf53SsvZN69brZrD-YplW4BnCsp7SZrLJW1ZnzwW7xjwdMW2l1FbS7dQvpRW7Ql3Qg9lw8R1W505jnv7BNZvvN5MLw4ZVCgH1W8tPGHZ3dJ59LW30VDY-79fK_kN8fdr8wjY6PnW4Pntqj9d-_bdW4txCbN1nFnd0W4NPkgk2gxLxbW5kpl2v3J-6mmW8gQd0M5DKl0PdtkM1204) and am standing by once materials are ready.

Ensuring that hydropower facilities are resilient to cyber threats is critical to the nation’s energy security. To that end, Training, Outreach, and Recruiting for Cybersecurity in Hydropower (TORCH) is supporting training and recruitment for the future cybersecurity workforce in hydropower. To learn more about the program and free curriculum for undergraduate students, contact [Penny McKenzie](https://info.pnnl.gov/e3t/Ctc/OI+113/c17Ms04/VVFJJS7zTV-HW60Gk837Hc4xfW67tPB755D2Y1N1k24Y23qgyTW6N1vHY6lZ3mdW8SFBG02QSPGrW73QvVQ7sjcwbW7C0H286krZw_W15F1SX8t2ZCKVmySBk1fLPVtW4Q4mDH1RbNQkW7BdKZf53SsvZN69brZrD-YplW4BnCsp7SZrLJW1ZnzwW7xjwdMW2l1FbS7dQvpRW7Ql3Qg9lw8R1W505jnv7BNZvvN5MLw4ZVCgH1W8tPGHZ3dJ59LW30VDY-79fK_kN8fdr8wjY6PnW4Pntqj9d-_bdW4txCbN1nFnd0W4NPkgk2gxLxbW5kpl2v3J-6mmW8gQd0M5DKl0PdtkM1204).

subject: NSF Informational Seminar and Q&A
description:
> This was an excellent opportunity to meet with Dr. Margaret Martonosi, Ellen Zagura, and Subrata Acharya from the National Science Foundation (NSF)  Computer Information Science & Engineering (CISE) directorate, and learn more about funding opportunities and how to navigate CISE funding opportunities.  Additional topics covered include ESPCoR, Technology Innovation Partners (TIP),  Growing Research Access for National Transformative  Equity and Diversity (GRANTED).

Meeting Info

> Nov 17 08:30 - 13:00 @ Akasofu 501 - NSF program officers from the Computer and Information Science & Engineering directorate will be holding in-person informational seminars and Q&A sessions on Friday November 17. **Participants will also have the opportunity to meet individually with NSF staff**
> 
> 08:30 Registration                                     
> 09:00 Welcome & introductions                                     
> 09:30 Overview and funding opportunities in CISE                                     
> 10:15 Break                                     
> 10:30 Cyberinfrastructure, Instrumentation, CI training                                     
> 11:00 EPSCoR                                     
> 11:30 GRANTED, TIP and Education/Curriculum program                                     
> 12:00 Lunch                                     
> 13:00 Proposal writing for early and mid career faculty and staff                                     
> 14:30 Closing remarks                                     
> 14:45 1-on-1 meeting opportunities with NSF programmatic staff

Notes
-----

### CISE - Computer Information Science & Engineering

*   1 of 8 NSF directorates
*   4 CISE units
*   Dr. Margaret Martonosi, Ellen Zagura, and Subrata Acharya
*   $1 B Budget
*   Speak to the value of CISE in other contexts.  Multi Disciplinary

#### Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure (OAC)

#### Computing and Communication Foundation (CCF)

#### Computer and Network Systems (CNS)

#### Information and Intelligence Systems (IIS)

*   Energy Sustainability for Computing
*   AI Trustworthyness
*   Differential Privacy
*   Zero Knowledge Proof
*   Homomorphic Encrption
*   CSGrad4US
*   [https://ms-cc.org](https://ms-cc.org)
*   [https://access-ci.org](https://access-ci.org)
*   **Arghya Das** [akdas@alaska.edu](mailto:akdas@alaska.edu)
*   Orion Lawlor
*   Leadership Class Computing Facility (LCCF) $500M
*   Tribal Serving University (TCU)

EPSCoR
------

JD Swanson

GRANTED, TIP and Education/Curriculum program
---------------------------------------------

### TIP - Technology Innovation Partners

*   RIE - Regional Innovation Engine

### GRANTED:  Growing Research Access for National Transformative  Equity and Diversity

*   Workforce Development (EWF)
*   ExENT
*   Energy Leadership Accelerator (ELA) - ACEP Award

### Institutional research capacity building

*   Expand AI - Interdiscipinary / MSI
*   CIVIC
*   BRAIDED Food Security (St. Paul)
*   Community Engagement

Proposal Writing
----------------

### Merritt Review Process

### Writing proposal that get turned into Panels

### Writing to help Panelists understand your Proposal

*   Panel does not determine the final decision
*   Panelist input is a peer review process and provides heavy input.
*   You are writing to Program Managers and Panelist
*   Make what they are looking for is easy to find.
*   Use language of the review criteria
*   Don't assume that reviewers will know your Jargon
*   Make sure the most important things receive the most space.
*   One page project summary is the most important part.  Most panelists make up their mind here.
*   Intellectual Merritt and Broader Impacts
*   Detailed research /eval / impact plan (with a timeline)
*   Enabling support for Broader Impacts
*   Award Search  for other proposals and Broader Impacts
*   Qualifications of Key Personnel
*   50% of CISE goes to CORE
*   PEP - Project Execution Plan
*   How is it Innovative or potentially transformative?
*   How will it advance knowledge
*   Who will be intersted in these outcomes
*   What are the anticipated outcomes
*   How might these products or findings be useful on a broader scale.

EAGER proposals - $500k - Innovative  and High Risks (Discretion of Program Manager)

Research Contributions and Domain

How does it build on other work.  Reviewers like being referenced and supporting work they have done.

Broader Impacts

*   Education / Coursework
*   Impact across disciplines
*   DEI
*   Datasets, Tools, Software
*   Actual Social Impacts

Be believable / A couple of real tangible outcomes

Gotchas

*   Importance
*   Problem not scienctifically or socetally imprtant.
*   Week, vauge or no connection to STEM
*   Releveant literature not cited.
*   Methods
*   Inadequate or inappropriate design
*   missing domain scientiests

Ignoring requirements stated int eh solicitation or PAPPG

Don't oversell your self or projects.

NSF CISE CAREER Workshop

### Find programs and POs that might fit your work

*   Plus current CISE solicitation topics
*   Information/ Computing/ Software/ Training/ Support Resources

Solicitations
-------------

Secure and Trustworty Cyberspace (SaTC)

Computer Science for all (CSforALL)

[https://www.nsf.gov/publications/](https://www.nsf.gov/publications/)

### Expand AI

*   (track 1 MSI) that do not have AI program
*   Vitual Office hours Dec 18th (EST 3-4pm)
*   Jan-Mar 2024 windows

Smart and connected Communities

*   Research Program

CIVIC Program

*   Implementation Program
*   Use inspired research.

Workforce Development for CS

subject: Eielson  EATON Project
description:
### Attendees

*   Dayne Broderson
*   John Haverlack
*   WIll Fisher

### Stake Holders

*   Edward Buck
*   Suvik Chandra

### Discussion

*   ERDC - Energy Resilience
*   Energy Resilience on Eileson Air Force Base
*   Evolved into an onsite data collection team.
*   ACEP would be boots on the ground to collect data for ~$40k.

#### Data Collection

*   Proprietary databases
*   2nd Data collection system at higher resolution
*   Grafana Dashboard for browsing data
*   50000 samples per second
*   Created meter network with meters not having any ablity to change the state of the system.

### Phase 1

*   ~$40k.
*   ACEP has been a rock start team for Eielson
*   Actually able to identify events

### Phase 2

*   ~$150k

### Phase 3 - Current Phase

[https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1HTiM0DlvGQWjkpyA2ZGIYR5vj6\_xlYXs](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1HTiM0DlvGQWjkpyA2ZGIYR5vj6_xlYXs)

> Phase 3 might not be the official phase name.

*   Eaton is the primary for the proposal
*   Need a new Suvik for this project
*   Breaking into the control side of things
*   ATO - (Authority to Operate) by EATON
*   Augmented Intelligence
*   Need to integrate to a private DoD network.
*   Raina Collins has experience with ATO process
*   ACEP will be subjected to ATO but it's not our problem
*   ACEP will be aligned with ATO

#### ACEP primary mission

*   Restore Data collection process
*   Make datasets available to research and operational partners (GVEA?)
*   Control and Monitoring of the system.

#### Timeline

*   Resume - to share with Eaton.
*   Solicitation is expected by Army Corp of Engineers this week
*   EATON will ask us for statement of work and budget
*   2 Year Project for $700,000
*   About $220k per year for ACEP
*   Students / Grad Student
*   Travel
*   Team Labor
*   Possible Partnering with CERL (Construction Engineering Research Lab) - Managing Contracts
*   Draft to Edward by 2023-11-17
*   Edward drafted a scope of work for ACEP.
*   Would like to have a holistic view of data with GVEA to start identifying power anomalies.
*   Possible Homomorphic Encryption Use
*   Additional Off Base Meters with High Precision Time
*   PTP
*   High Availability of Servcies
*   NREL - Golden - in Colorado - EATON leases a Lab

#### Shadow Statement of Work

*   Vague statement of goals and outcomes
*   Not Timeline
*   To Prepare for as soon as Jan/Feb for a proposal

#### Data Diode

*   EATON has their own Data Diodes
*   This may or may not be part of the project.
*   How to get not CUI data to a non-DOD network.

### In Scope

*   IaM
*   Zero Trust
*   Review ERMDA

Jody
----

*   Give us an overview of Eaton work thus far.
*   Consider how to do this on premise.

### **APPLICATION FORMS AND TEMPLATES**

The following forms and templates may be used as part of the application submission. subject: DOE Announces NOI for $4.8 Million in Secure Comms Development and Demonstrations Funding
description:
DOE Announces NOI for $4.8 Million in Secure Comms Development and Demonstrations Funding
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) today [**announced a notice of intent**](https://lnks.gd/l/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9..bYZ5JWvzvlqIRjx4TY1F_QLFSeAlY2C2BCCOYxTPcsI/s/2939946849/br/231268432639-l) (NOI) for the Office of Electricity to issue a $4.8 million funding opportunity announcement (FOA). This FOA aims to support the development and demonstration of technologies, tools, or systems that enable secure communications of data and control messaging between grid edge infrastructure and distribution system operators.

The grid edge is where utility service ends and customer equipment starts. Specifically, the grid edge begins at customers’ meter points and includes their own equipment, software, and controls. Examples include rooftop solar systems, electric vehicle charging stations, and energy storage solutions.

The FOA’s objective is to develop and evaluate the effectiveness of new communications solutions on utility infrastructure, and to demonstrate how legacy grid communications infrastructure and operating standards can be updated to support coordination of distributed energy resources on the distribution system. To keep the lights on for consumers, it is critical that the grid quickly responds and recovers from disruption.

*   If DOE issues the FOA, it will be posted at [**Grants.gov**](https://lnks.gd/l/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJidWxsZXRpbl9saW5rX2lkIjoxMDIsInVyaSI6ImJwMjpjbGljayIsInVybCI6Imh0dHA6Ly93d3cuZ3JhbnRzLmdvdj91dG1fbWVkaXVtPWVtYWlsJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9Z292ZGVsaXZlcnkiLCJidWxsZXRpbl9pZCI6IjIwMjMxMTIwLjg1OTI2MzIxIn0.CvVKXCKLN7E_iRYsk6QWpjVoXl0uzahLIFQKJqHd45E/s/2939946849/br/231268432639-l) and at [**FedConnect**](https://lnks.gd/l/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJidWxsZXRpbl9saW5rX2lkIjoxMDMsInVyaSI6ImJwMjpjbGljayIsInVybCI6Imh0dHA6Ly93d3cuZmVkY29ubmVjdC5uZXQ_dXRtX21lZGl1bT1lbWFpbCZ1dG1fc291cmNlPWdvdmRlbGl2ZXJ5IiwiYnVsbGV0aW5faWQiOiIyMDIzMTEyMC44NTkyNjMyMSJ9.p-S0-TWP3YpX8kqanfQpG-stozzLdXK0VBBg-1P7mwI/s/2939946849/br/231268432639-l). Entities interested in applying for awards under the FOA are strongly encouraged to register now at these sites to receive notification of announcements regarding the FOA. Applications can only be submitted through [**Grants.gov**](https://lnks.gd/l/eyJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJidWxsZXRpbl9saW5rX2lkIjoxMDQsInVyaSI6ImJwMjpjbGljayIsInVybCI6Imh0dHA6Ly93d3cuZ3JhbnRzLmdvdj91dG1fbWVkaXVtPWVtYWlsJnV0bV9zb3VyY2U9Z292ZGVsaXZlcnkiLCJidWxsZXRpbl9pZCI6IjIwMjMxMTIwLjg1OTI2MzIxIn0.M_It_XURg6qYknSEcAH7Mz29X_1alnYJRM40sLWfp3k/s/2939946849/br/231268432639-l).

subject: ACEP - C3 AI - DoE GRIP Grants
description:
> Nov 22:  Arghya, Dayne, Jody and John met to review this opportunity.   We recommend setting up a meeting with C3.AI to discuss possible collaboration opportunities.

*   Find additional notes in Obsidian
*   And [Google Drive](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1w-BuIg_sKfEdbE7ZLJDb8cXJAJrqeN5E?usp=drive_link)

Subject: ACEP | C3 AI | Department of Energy GRIP Grants | $3.9B funding oppurtunity      
Date: Tue, 21 Nov 2023 21:43:57 +0000      
From: Nicholas Galanos [Nicholas.Galanos@c3.ai](mailto:Nicholas.Galanos@c3.ai)      
To: [jlkasper@alaska.edu](mailto:jlkasper@alaska.edu) [jlkasper@alaska.edu](mailto:jlkasper@alaska.edu), [gwen.holdmann@alaska.edu](mailto:gwen.holdmann@alaska.edu) [gwen.holdmann@alaska.edu](mailto:gwen.holdmann@alaska.edu), [jbharris@alaska.edu](mailto:jbharris@alaska.edu) [jbharris@alaska.edu](mailto:jbharris@alaska.edu), [ACEP.info@alaska.edu](mailto:ACEP.info@alaska.edu) [ACEP.info@alaska.edu](mailto:ACEP.info@alaska.edu)

Jeremy,

Really hope you are doing well! ACEP is doing great work within the energy space. I wanted to reach out to discuss potential partnership opportunities **concerning the January 12th concept papers for the Grid Deployment Office. Topic area 2: Smart Grid Grants allows for institutions of higher education to join.** Overall grants are $1B, with typical grant at $50M. 

C3 AI is a world leading AI/ML enterprise solutions company. We are conducting work with the National Labs and DoE. C3 AI’s CTO and President Ed Abbo also recently presented to the subcommittee on energy, climate, and grid security on “The Role of Artificial Intelligence in Powering America’s Future.” We are also connecting with the Deputy Secretary of DoE and head of Grid Modernization within GDO, because of interest in our AI/ML solutions to the grid. C3 AI has years of experience related to Grid applications, utilities, and energy to include:

*   Reducing power outages and threats
*   Ensuring optimal health of advanced metering infrastructure (AMI)
*   Developing enterprise AI for digital engineering, providing digital twin capabilities
*   Employing enterprise AI for stakeholder intelligence, energy management, and monitoring ESG materiality
*   Leveraging edge computing to enable smart grid and smart city services
*   Providing cybersecurity and intelligence forecasts related to the energy
*   Enhancing advanced manufacturing processes      
     

Our logos include **Shell, ConEd, Duke Energy.**  We also have experience working with UARCs, such as work at the Applied Physics Lab at Johns Hopkins/DoD. I would love to get time with your team to see how we can partner, whether through grants or to help on current R&D. Currently, we are working with a National Lab, taking TRL 2 concepts to TRL 6, related to cybersecurity, the grid and digital engineering. Also in terms of GDO funding, **we are looking to potentially partner as we move closer to this second round of funding.** C3 AI is uniquely positioned to solve these requirements.

We’d love to set up a time to connect to see how our two teams can work together on this next round, or to see if C3 AI can help solve any problems your team is facing today. Please let me know some availabilities that work to set up a meeting. We look forward to hearing from you soon! 

Best,

Nicholas Galanos      
Senior Director, Strategic Solutions      
Tysons, Virginia

subject: FERPA Training
description:
Hello everyone,

  
 

Thank you for your interest in participating as an internship mentor for Summer 2024! 

  
 

To participate as a mentor in the internship program, you are required to refresh your training on the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). FERPA training is required for all UAF employees who have access to student records, supervise students, and/or have educational/instructional responsibilities.

**To participate in the internship program, your FERPA training must be completed no later than 5pm on December 8th.** 

You may access FERPA training through UAOnline and myUA. Instructions on how to access the training can be found here: [https://www.alaska.edu/studentservices/files/ferpa/FERPA.pdf](https://www.alaska.edu/studentservices/files/ferpa/FERPA.pdf)

The training only takes 10-15 minutes to complete.

**Once you have completed your training, please send your certificate/screenshot to me at** [**caellis5@alaska.edu**](mailto:caellis5@alaska.edu) **as a PDF.** Please let me know if you have any questions.

Thank you,

\--  
 

**Cassandra Ellis** (She/Her)

Senior HR Coordinator and Senior Recruiting Specialist

University of Alaska Fairbanks

Alaska Center for Energy and Power

Joseph E. Usibelli Engineering Learning and Innovation Building

1764 Tanana Loop, Room 415

P.O. Box 755910

Fairbanks, AK 99775-5910

subject: Review ACEP Infosec Interships
description:
\[Happy New Year, folks. Bumping to the top of your inbox!\]

  
 

Applications are still open for the internship program until January 8. However, we already have 50+ applications that have been submitted, and every project has applicants! This would be a great time to start combing through the applications, as we will need your final top 3 interview choices by January 12.

  
 

**Now:** browse applicants-- they will continue to populate as they are submitted. I have a "notepad" set up on your project page so you can take notes on applicants as you read them.

**Jan 9-12:** Application closes. Decide + submit your top 3 choices for interviews on your project page.

**End of January-mid Feb:** Patty and I will be scheduling interviews.

  
 

FIRST!! Please watch this [6 minute video](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1gFoxWr9UPdTua1-GOXWqAVUtCxIT-1_B/view?usp=sharing) where I walk through the different pieces of the interface and the process for submitting your interview choices. It's pretty much the same as last year, but there is a new process for submitting your final selections. You can listen to it at double time and hear Chipmunk Annalise cruise through it in 3 minutes if that's all the time you have.

  
 

Then you can head over to the [interface](https://airtable.com/invite/l?inviteId=invhUDAR6lmdPQyCC&inviteToken=5327c0f0a7ae9905012d88fcac6904f5d02c480783ca0f124f0667c7bb9b8197&utm_medium=email&utm_source=product_team&utm_content=transactional-alerts). If you haven't made an Airtable account before, you'll need to do that through your UAF account. Let me know if you have any questions.

  
 

Thanks!

subject: Obsidian Auto Update
description:
```plaintext
#!/bin/bash

# Function to compare semantic versions
# Returns 1 if $1 is greater than $2, 0 otherwise
version_gt() { 
    test "$(echo "$@" | tr " " "\n" | sort -V | head -n 1)" != "$1"; 
}

# URL to check for Obsidian updates
OBSIDIAN_URL="https://obsidian.md/download"

# Fetch the latest Obsidian download page
HTML=$(wget -q -O - "$OBSIDIAN_URL")

# Extract the latest version and download link
LATEST_VERSION=$(echo "$HTML" | grep -oP 'href="https://github.com/obsidianmd/obsidian-releases/releases/download/v\K[0-9.]+(?=/obsidian_[0-9.]+_amd64.deb)')
DOWNLOAD_LINK=$(echo "$HTML" | grep -oP 'href="\Khttps://github.com/obsidianmd/obsidian-releases/releases/download/v[0-9.]+/obsidian_[0-9.]+_amd64.deb')

# Check installed version
INSTALLED_VERSION=$(dpkg -l | grep obsidian | awk '{print $3}')

# Compare versions
if version_gt $LATEST_VERSION $INSTALLED_VERSION; then
    echo "Updating Obsidian from $INSTALLED_VERSION to $LATEST_VERSION..."

    # Download the latest version
    FILENAME="/var/tmp/obsidian_${LATEST_VERSION}_amd64.deb"
    wget -q -O "$FILENAME" "$DOWNLOAD_LINK"

    # Install the new version
    dpkg -i "$FILENAME"
else
    echo "Obsidian is up-to-date (version $INSTALLED_VERSION)."
fi
```

subject: URGENT - Action needed- Third-party emailing services InboxSearch for all messages with label InboxRemove label Inbox from this conversation
description:
John and Yuri,

This came to me from University relations. I know that the storytelling team uses [Constant Contact](https://www.constantcontact.com/), but I am not sure of other 3rd party platforms that we use at ACEP. Do you know any others?

Thanks!

Amanda

\---------- Forwarded message ---------    
From: **Marmian Grimes** <[mlgrimes@alaska.edu](mailto:mlgrimes@alaska.edu)\>    
Date: Wed, Jan 3, 2024 at 4:43 PM    
Subject: URGENT - Action needed- Third-party emailing services    
To: Marmian Grimes <[mlgrimes@alaska.edu](mailto:mlgrimes@alaska.edu)\>    
Cc: Theresa Bakker <[tabakker@alaska.edu](mailto:tabakker@alaska.edu)\>    
 

Hi everyone,

We have received notice from Google and Yahoo that, effective Feb. 1, they will implement a new security technology called [DMARC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DMARC) for any organization that processes more than 5,000 emails a day. The university falls into this category.

Without going into too much technical detail, this means that any third-party platform we use to send emails (things like MailChimp or Salesforce or Cision) must be DMARC compliant or we risk getting our IP addresses blacklisted, which would make mass distribution of emails impossible. 

**No later than close-of-business on Jan. 9,** please send me a list of any third-party platforms you use to send mass emails to people and the point-of-contact on your team for those platforms (so, for example, I am point-of-contact for our Merit subscription). If you use a PR or marketing agency, you should also find out whether they use a third-party platform to send emails on your behalf and, if so, list those as well. I’ll share that with the IT folks and they should be able to help with next steps.

Thanks,

MG

Marmian Grimes    
Public information officer    
University of Alaska Fairbanks    
907-474-7902 (office)    
907-460-4750 (mobile)    
[marmian.grimes@alaska.edu](mailto:marmian.grimes@alaska.edu)    
@MarmianGrimes

\--    
 

\-Amanda Byrd

subject: Funding: Up to $70M to Address Cyber Hazards
description: > **Funding: Up to $70M to Address Cyber Hazards** This week the Department of Energy [**announced**](https://www.energy.gov/articles/doe-announces-70-million-strengthen-energy-sector-against-physical-and-cyber-hazards?utm_medium=email&utm_source=govdelivery) up to $70 million in competitive funding to support research into technologies designed to increase resilience and reduce risks to energy delivery infrastructure from a variety of hazards, including cyber and physical threats, natural disasters, and climate-change fueled extreme weather events.
